coreGitAll.name: Graphic Industry Business Practices
coreGitAll.description: Business practices related to the graphics industry; business models, cost and rate analysis, marketing and management approaches.
requirements: minimum senior standing
credit allowed only for GIT432 OR GIT532 OR visiting university student

coreGitAll.name: Digital Workflow in Graphic Industries
coreGitAll.description: Digital production system analysis for content creation, automation output of graphic information to print and Web, including networking and job tracking.
requirements: applied science (graphic info tech) BAS major
GIT303 OR applied science (Internet & Web Dev) BAS major OR GIT215 with a C or better
GIT303
credit is only allowed for GIT450 OR GIT550 OR GIT598 (Digital Workflow in Graphic Industries) OR visiting university student

coreGitAll.name: Professional Portfolio Design and Presentation
coreGitAll.description: Digital media portfolio design and production to include planning, audience analysis, content selection, authoring tools and formats, production, copyright considerations, marketing and delivery. Should be taken in the last semester of the program.
requirements: applied Science (internet & web development) BAS major OR GIT303
senior standing
Pre- OR Corequisites: GIT480 OR visiting university student

coreGitAll.name: Senior Project
coreGitAll.description: Capstone project experience refining skills in communication, research and information retrieval, critical analysis and criticism, and demonstrating technical competence in each student's area of study.
requirements: minimum senior standing

coreBas.name: Digital publishing
coreBas.description: Web and print publication design and production using industry-standard composition software, proofing, and output devices.
requirements: GIT 230 with C or better or Applied Science (Internet and Web Development) BAS or Applied Science (Graphic Information Technology) BAS major OR Visiting University Student

coreBas.name: Multimedia Design, Planning, and Storyboards
coreBas.description: The creative process of generating ideas, conceptualizing projects, planning, designing, story boarding, and presenting interactive multimedia products.
requirements: GIT 230 with C or better; minimum junior standing OR Applied Science (Graphic Information Technology) BAS or Applied Science (Internet and Web Development) BAS major OR Visiting University Student

coreBas.name: Digital Video Techniques
coreBas.description: Covers video production, including planning, pre-production, production, post-production and online video technologies and how video is an integral part of the graphic information industry. Concentrates on commercial and client-driven video production.
prerequisites: Applied Science (Graphic Information Technology) BAS major or Applied Science (Internet and Web Development) BAS major or GIT 230 with C or better OR Visiting University Student

coreBas.name: Commercial Photography
coreBas.description: Digital image capture, and output in a commercial studio emphasizing publishing workflow.
requirements: GIT 230 with C or better or Applied Science (Graphic Information Technology) BAS or Applied Science (Internet and Web Development) BAS major OR Visiting University Student

coreBasIwd.name: Advanced Web Markup and Scripting
coreBasIwd.description: Industry-standard programming languages and techniques to add user interactivity to graphic information Web sites and Web applications.
requirements: GIT 310 or 337 OR Visiting University Student

coreBasIwd.name: Introduction to Web Authoring
coreBasIwd.description: Website planning and evaluation using industry-standard languages.
requirements: Credit is allowed for only GIT 215 or GIT 310 OR Visiting University Student
topics: Authoring HTML for SEO, Usability, and Accessibility

coreBasIwd.name: Image Editing and Manipulation
coreBasIwd.description: Theory and application of advanced image editing and raster techniques for reproduction and dissemination.
requirements: GIT 230 with C or better or Applied Science (Graphic Information Technology) BAS or Applied Science (Internet and Web Development) BAS major OR Visiting University Student

coreBasIwd.name: Web Content Design
coreBasIwd.description: User-centered design principles for visual content on the World Wide Web with emphasis on content strategy, user experience, coding and interactivity.
requirements: GIT 215 with C or better
GIT 230 OR Applied Science (Graphic Information Technology) BAS or Applied Science (Internet and Web Development) BAS major
Credit is allowed for only GIT 310 or GIT 337 OR Visiting University Student

coreBasIwd.name: Information Design and Usability
coreBasIwd.description: Design and technology solutions for increasing Website usability and methods of organizing information to improve the user experience.
requirements: Minimum junior standing OR Visiting University Student

coreBasIwd.name: Web Site Design and Internet/Web Technologies
coreBasIwd.description: Design, authoring, standards, protocols, tools and techniques for development for different Web-based technologies.
requirements: GIT 310 or 337 OR Visiting University Student

coreBasIwd.name: Website and E-Commerce Strategies
coreBasIwd.description: E-Commerce site management, marketing analytics and e-commerce business models.
requirements: GIT 414; Credit is allowed for only GIT 435 or GIT 535 or GIT 598 (Website & E-Commerce Strategy) OR Visiting University Student

coreBsAll.name: The ASU Experience
coreBsAll.description: Students will learn about ASU's mission as the New American University, the importance and benefits of an entrepreneurial approach to problem solving, solutions to sustainability challenges, and the importance of social embeddedness. Additionally, through various course discussions and assignments, students will examine the concept of academic integrity and its potential impact on their future, gain awareness of the value of engaging in research activities, and learn about taking an interdisciplinary perspective.
requirements: Ira A. Fulton Schools of Engineering - The Polytechnic School student OR Visiting University Student

coreBsAll.name: Introduction to Human Systems Engineering
coreBsAll.description: Introduces basic principles, methods and theories of psychology and applications to engineering problems relevant to human systems. Gives particular attention to the intersection of psychology and engineering. Students learn brain anatomy and physiology, sensation and perception, cognition, social systems and research methods so that they are able to design systems consistent with human capabilities and limitations.

coreBsAll.name: Graphic Communications
coreBsAll.description: Processes involved in design, asset generation, transmission, production and evaluation of visual content.

coreBsAll.name: First-Year Composition
coreBsAll.description: Discovers, organizes and develops ideas in relation to the writer's purpose, subject and audience. Emphasizes modes of written discourse and effective use of rhetorical principles.
requirements: For students for whom English is not the native language, enroll in ENG107 (or WAC107)

coreBsAll.name: First-Year Composition
coreBsAll.description: Critical reading and writing; emphasizes strategies of academic discourse. Research paper required.
requirements: ENG101 OR ENG107 with C or better OR visiting university student

coreBsAll.name: College Algebra
coreBsAll.description: Linear functions, quadratic functions, general polynomial functions, rational functions, systems of linear equations, logarithmic and exponential functions.
requirements: ALEKS score of 60 or higher OR visiting university student

coreBsAll.name: Creative Thinking and Design Visualization
coreBsAll.description: Fundamental methods, concepts and techniques of creative thinking, ideation and problem solving, including communication and societal influences. Examines drawing and design visualization, from sketching to data graphics.

coreBsAll.name: Introduction to Web Authoring
coreBsAll.description: Website planning and evaluation using industry-standard languages.
requirements: Credit is allowed for only GIT 215 or GIT 310 OR Visiting University Student
topics: Authoring HTML for SEO, Usability, and Accessibility

coreBsAll.name: Digital Illustration in Publishing
coreBsAll.description: Raster and vector illustration in publishing.
requirements: MAT117 with C or better

coreBsAll.name: Understanding the Enterprise
coreBsAll.description: Introduces essential functions required in technology-based and innovative enterprises and viewed in the context of their relationship to each other; examines the enterprise's role in society.

coreBsAll.name: Introduction to Commercial Print
coreBsAll.description: Provides an overview of current print technology, a basic understanding of the print process and current workflows.
requirements: Applied Science (Graphic Info Tech) BAS, Applied Science (Internet & Web Dev) BAS, Graphic Info Tech BS, Graphic Info Tech (Full-Stack Web Development) BS or Graphic Info Tech (User Experience) BS major OR Visiting University Student

coreBsAll.name: Digital publishing
coreBsAll.description: Web and print publication design and production using industry-standard composition software, proofing, and output devices.
requirements: GIT 230 with C or better or Applied Science (Internet and Web Development) BAS or Applied Science (Graphic Information Technology) BAS major OR Visiting University Student

coreBsAll.name: Multimedia Design, Planning, and Storyboards
coreBsAll.description: The creative process of generating ideas, conceptualizing projects, planning, designing, story boarding, and presenting interactive multimedia products.
requirements: GIT 230 with C or better; minimum junior standing OR Applied Science (Graphic Information Technology) BAS or Applied Science (Internet and Web Development) BAS major OR Visiting University Student

coreBsAll.name: Digital Video Techniques
coreBsAll.description: Covers video production, including planning, pre-production, production, post-production and online video technologies and how video is an integral part of the graphic information industry. Concentrates on commercial and client-driven video production.
prerequisites: Applied Science (Graphic Information Technology) BAS major or Applied Science (Internet and Web Development) BAS major or GIT 230 with C or better OR Visiting University Student

coreBsAll.name: Commercial Photography
coreBsAll.description: Digital image capture, and output in a commercial studio emphasizing publishing workflow.
requirements: GIT 230 with C or better or Applied Science (Graphic Information Technology) BAS or Applied Science (Internet and Web Development) BAS major OR Visiting University Student

coreBsAll.name: Copyright and Intellectual Property in the Electronic Age
coreBsAll.description: Explores issues related to copyright and intellectual property laws, with emphasis on electronic environment.
requirements: English 102, 105, or 108 with C or better
minimum 45 hours
Credit only allowed for TWC451 OR TWC551 OR visiting university student

requirements: GIT 215 with C or better
GIT 230 OR Applied Science (Graphic Information Technology) BAS or Applied Science (Internet and Web Development) BAS major
Credit is allowed for only GIT 310 or GIT 337 OR Visiting University Student

coreUx.name: Information Design and Usability
coreUx.description: Design and technology solutions for increasing Website usability and methods of organizing information to improve the user experience.
requirements: Minimum junior standing OR Visiting University Student

coreUx.name: Web Site Design and Internet/Web Technologies
coreUx.description: Design, authoring, standards, protocols, tools and techniques for development for different Web-based technologies.
requirements: GIT 310 or 337 OR Visiting University Student

coreUx.name: Fundamentals of Writing for Digital Media
coreUx.description: Foundational concepts and technologies of writing for a variety of digital media.
requirements: ENG 102, 105, or 108 with C or better
minimum 45 hours OR Visiting University Student

coreUx.name: Visualizing Data and Information
coreUx.description: Covers how to process data and information in ways that help discover what's important about the information and what the clearest way is to communicate that information. Covers how to manage data and use a variety of software tools to communicate patterns and tell visual stories, as well as how to make choices in visualization style in ways that will assist an audience to effectively interact with and process the information.
requirements: minimum 45 hours
Credit is allowed for only TWC 414 or TWC 494 or TWC 514 or TWC 598 OR Visiting University Student

coreUx.name: User Experience
coreUx.description: Explores principles, techniques and tools of user experience (UX), including user and task analysis, user-centered design and usability testing.
requirements: ENG 102, 105, or 108 with C or better
minimum 45 hours
Credit is allowed for only TWC 444 or TWC 544 OR Visiting University Student

coreUx.name: Statistics for Human Systems Research
coreUx.description: Basic methods of exploratory data analysis (including graphics) and statistical computing methods, including a detailed look at hypothesis testing, effect size and power analysis, as well as some methods for dealing with categorical and discrete data. Introduces both correlation/regression and analysis of variance (ANOVA), as well as common statistical software.
requirements: HSE 101 or PSY 101 with C or better
MAT 117 or higher with C or better OR Visiting University Student

coreUx.name: Human Systems Integration
coreUx.description: Reviews human systems integration (HSI), which is basically systems engineering from a human-centered perspective. Research, theory and methodological approach as applied to a variety of systems ranging from transportation systems to medical and military systems. Discusses handbook chapters and specific examples of human systems integration.
requirements: HSE 101 or PSY 101 with C or better
Credit is allowed for only HSE 225 or IEE 225 OR Visiting University Student

coreUx.name: Experimental Methods for Human Systems Research
coreUx.description: Introduces the basics of research methodology as applied in human systems engineering. Quantitative and experimental design from an applied perspective. Guided study of the process of conducting research within human systems engineering. Project topics range from research question generation and literature review to reporting of results.
requirements: ECN 221, ECN 231, EGR 280, HSE 230, IEE 380, PSY 230, STP 226, STP 420, or STS 401 with C or better
ENG 101, 105, or 107 with C or better OR Visiting University Student

coreUx.name: Qualitative Research Methods
coreUx.description: Reviews basics of qualitative research with applications to human systems engineering. Covers fundamental concepts of reliability and validity, and considers best practices in survey, questionnaire, interview and observation methods. Introduces and applies content analysis and grounded theory approaches for analyzing and interpreting qualitative data (e.g., interview transcripts and open-ended survey responses). All concepts are taught with an applied focus and real-world examples.
requirements: ENG 101, 105, or 107 with C or better
HSE 290 or PSY 290 with C or better OR Visiting University Student

coreUx.name: Human-Computer Interaction
coreUx.description: Theories, methods, and findings concerning the usability of computer systems and the design of effective user interfaces.
requirements: HSE 101 or PSY 101 with C or better OR Visiting University Student

requirements: GIT 215 with C or better
GIT 230 OR Applied Science (Graphic Information Technology) BAS or Applied Science (Internet and Web Development) BAS major
Credit is allowed for only GIT 310 or GIT 337 OR Visiting University Student

coreBsFs.name: Web Site Design and Internet/Web Technologies
coreBsFs.description: Design, authoring, standards, protocols, tools and techniques for development for different Web-based technologies.
requirements: GIT 310 or 337 OR Visiting University Student

coreBsFs.name: Advanced Web Markup and Scripting
coreBsFs.description: Industry-standard programming languages and techniques to add user interactivity to graphic information Web sites and Web applications.
requirements: GIT 310 or 337 OR Visiting University Student

coreBsFs.name: Multimedia Authoring, Scripting, and Production
coreBsFs.description: Extended application of industry-standard scripting languages and techniques to add user interactivity to graphic information websites and web applications.
requirements: GIT 417 with C or better OR Visiting University Student

coreBsFs.name: Information Technology Programming Logic
coreBsFs.description: Introduces basic analysis and synthesis procedures for an understanding of information system logical structures. Topics include: identifying organizational domains for potential automation, informational descriptions (scenarios) of those domains, and program structure and logical designs for potential problem/opportunity resolution. Uses graphical and textual models to express the logic and uses Python to implement the logic.
requirements: Credit is allowed for only IFT 101 or IFT 194 (Information Technology Programming Logic) OR Visiting University Student

coreBsFs.name: Information Modeling, Storage, and Retrieval
coreBsFs.description: Covers the different types of data modeling with emphasis on the relational model. Develop solutions for data modeling problems, starting with identifying user and data requirements. Fundamentals of database design going through the conceptual, logical and physical data modeling steps. Create relational databases in order to store data. Utilize Structured Query Language (SQL) to represent, retrieve, and manage a database. Students learn how applications connect to databases, and interact with them.
requirements: IFT 101 with C or better OR Visiting University Student

coreBsFs.name: Introduction to Java Technologies
coreBsFs.description: Introduces Java as a platform for application development. Fundamental concepts of the Java language (classes, objects, conditions, loops, arrays), object-oriented programming and design (inheritance, polymorphism, interfaces), exceptions, and basics of the user interface programming.
requirements: FT 101 with C or better OR Visiting University Student

coreBsFs.name: Middleware Programming and Database Security
coreBsFs.description: Covers the main concepts of middleware technologies. Includes the various methodologies used to integrate applications, databases and Web services. Students develop multilevel applications using programming/scripting languages (such as PHP, Java, Python, Perl) which access data stored in a database. Middleware programs typically control database access and protect database SQL programs from security breaches. Students access the data from applications and other Web technologies such as XML, as well as protecting the data from unauthorized access.
requirements: Graphic Information Technology (Full-Stack Web Development) BS major
GIT 215 with C or better OR IFT 301 with C or better; IFT 383 with C or better
Credit is allowed for only ACO 321 or IFT 458 OR Visiting University Student

electivesBas.suggested: Any needed lower division general studies requirement OR elective
Any needed lower division general studies requirement OR elective
Any needed lower division general studies requirement OR elective

electivesBasIwd.suggested: Any needed lower division general studies requirement OR elective
Any needed lower division general studies requirement OR elective
Any needed lower division general studies requirement OR elective
Any needed lower division general studies requirement OR elective

fullStackElectivesOpts.name: Intermediate Database Management Systems
fullStackElectivesOpts.description: Fundamental methods in managing data-oriented systems. Relational, object and hierarchical data architectures. Query languages including SQL. Semantics of transaction processing. Database system architectures including cloud-based, client-server and embedded databases. Security and privacy issues associated with SQL-structured databases. Modern trends in data management including unstructured data type management, data mining and business analytics. Describes NoSQL data management platforms.
requirements: IFT 200 with C or better
Credit is allowed for only ACO 220 or ACO 320 or CSE 412 or IFT 300 (or IFT 433) or SER 322 OR Visiting University Student

fullStackElectivesOpts.name: Applied Programming Language for Information Technology
fullStackElectivesOpts.description: Object-oriented programming (OOP) with a focus on advanced techniques used in developing applications. Emphasizes problem solving using the software development life cycle. Supports application creation and testing through study of programming basics, data structures and OOP fundamentals resulting in a framework of collection classes students use to solve problems and create applications.
requirements: IFT 210 with C or better OR Visiting University Student

fullStackElectivesOpts.name: Information Design and Usability
fullStackElectivesOpts.description: Design and technology solutions for increasing Website usability and methods of organizing information to improve the user experience.
requirements: Minimum junior standing OR Visiting University Student

fullStackElectivesOpts.name: Website and E-Commerce Strategies
fullStackElectivesOpts.description: E-Commerce site management, marketing analytics and e-commerce business models.
requirements: GIT 414; Credit is allowed for only GIT 435 or GIT 535 or GIT 598 (Website & E-Commerce Strategy) OR Visiting University Student

fullStackElectivesOpts.name: Internship
fullStackElectivesOpts.description: Structured practical experience following a contract or plan, supervised by faculty and practitioners.
requirements: none

commercialPhoto.name: Image Editing and Manipulation
commercialPhoto.description: Theory and application of advanced image editing and raster techniques for reproduction and dissemination.
requirements: GIT 230 with C or better or Applied Science (Graphic Information Technology) BAS or Applied Science (Internet and Web Development) BAS major OR Visiting University Student

commercialPhoto.name: Color Reproduction Systems
commercialPhoto.description: Scientific analysis for the engineering of color reproduction systems and color models used in the graphics industry.
requirements: GIT 334; Credit is allowed for only GIT 437 or GIT 573

commercialPhoto.name: 360 Production
commercialPhoto.description: Overview of 360 photo and video capture and editing, immersive storytelling, and 360/VR. Students explore immersive storytelling (spherical/360/180) by producing various forms of VR video and photos and examining their use in communication, entertainment and industrial applications. Emphasizes technical skills required to produce immersive content from capture to distribution using industry standard NLE and specialty software. In addition, students actively research and analyze the role of this emerging technology and communication medium. Requires prior knowledge of video editing.
requirements: GIT 315
Credit is allowed for only GIT 445 or GIT 494 (360 Production) or GIT 545 or GIT 598 (360 Production) OR Visiting University Student

commercialPhoto.name: Advanced Commercial Photography
commercialPhoto.description: Studio-based class focusing on set design, advanced photographic techniques, raw workflow, marketing, business, and digital rights management.
requirements: GIT 384

commercialPrint.name: Printing Technology
commercialPrint.description: Theory and application of sheet and web press technology for offset-lithography, flexography, screen process, and digital printing.
requirements: GIT 250 OR Visiting University Student

commercialPrint.name: Structural and Aesthetic Package Design
commercialPrint.description: This course covers the basics of packaging design, including terminology, design theories (color, imagery, typography), and design psychologies as they pertain to designing the exterior of product packages. Additionally, structural packaging design and sustainable packaging will be studied. Students in this course will be designing and building several individual and sets of packages. Adobe InDesign and Adobe Illustrator will be used in the course, so students should have a good understanding of and practice with those applications. Adaptive/Active learning system used.
requirements: none

commercialPrint.name: Principles of Visual Communication
commercialPrint.description: Principles and tools of visual communication in print and electronic media, with an emphasis on document design, including typography and color.
requirements: ENG 102, 105, or 108 with C or better
minimum 45 hours
Credit is allowed for only TWC 411 or TWC 511 OR Visiting University Student

commercialVideo.name: Advanced Digital Video Techniques
commercialVideo.description: Advanced video creation and editing techniques including motion graphics, green screen technology, audio sweetening, crew and commercial production. Course culminates with a completed video production that is commercial and professional in nature.
requirements: GIT315

frontEndWebDev.name: Web Content Design
frontEndWebDev.description: User-centered design principles for visual content on the World Wide Web with emphasis on content strategy, user experience, coding and interactivity.
requirements: GIT 215 with C or better; GIT 230 OR Applied Science (Graphic Information Technology) BAS or Applied Science (Internet and Web Development) BAS major; Credit is allowed for only GIT 310 or GIT 337 OR Visiting University Student

frontEndWebDev.name: Web Site Design and Internet/Web Technologies
frontEndWebDev.description: Design, authoring, standards, protocols, tools and techniques for development for different Web-based technologies.
requirements: GIT 310 or 337 OR Visiting University Student

frontEndWebDev.name: Advanced Web Markup and Scripting
frontEndWebDev.description: Industry-standard programming languages and techniques to add user interactivity to graphic information Web sites and Web applications.
requirements: GIT 310 or 337 OR Visiting University Student

frontEndWebDev.name: Multimedia Authoring, Scripting, and Production
frontEndWebDev.description: Extended application of industry-standard scripting languages and techniques to add user interactivity to graphic information websites and web applications.
requirements: GIT 417 with C or better OR Visiting University Student

interactionDesign.name: Information Design and Usability
interactionDesign.description: Design and technology solutions for increasing Website usability and methods of organizing information to improve the user experience.
requirements: minimum junior standing OR Visiting University Student

interactionDesign.name: Cross-Media Design
interactionDesign.description: Strengthens design elements and principles. Explores, creates and critiques cross-media design work for print and digital outputs.
requirements: GIT 303
Credit is allowed for only GIT 350 or GIT 494 (Cross-Media Design Solutions) OR Visiting University Student

interactionDesign.name: New Media and Internet Technologies
interactionDesign.description: Project-based exploration of new media Internet technologies from a graphic technology prospective. Emphasizes how, why, and when new media can be used to enhance a Web site and the user's experience.
requirements: minimum junior standing; Credit is allowed for only GIT 402 or GIT 502

interactionDesign.name: Website and E-Commerce Strategies
interactionDesign.description: E-Commerce site management, marketing analytics and e-commerce business models.
requirements: GIT 414; Credit is allowed for only GIT 435 or GIT 535 or GIT 598 (Website & E-Commerce Strategy) OR Visiting University Student

motionGraphics.name: Topic: Spatial Design
motionGraphics.description: Covers topics of immediate or special interest to a faculty member and students.
requirements: none

motionGraphics.name: 3D Media Production
motionGraphics.description: Introduces basic 3D workflows and techniques. Topics covered include visual storytelling and composition, project workflows, 3D modeling, virtual cameras, texturing, shading and rendering.
requirements: GIT 230 with C or better OR Visiting University Student

motionGraphics.name: Computer Animation and Motion Graphics
motionGraphics.description: Covers basic 2D/3D animation and motion graphic techniques and principles. Topics covered include project workflows, key frames, path animation, motion principles, hierarchical structures, animated textures, lights, and cameras.
requirements: GIT 211 OR Visiting University Student

motionGraphics.name: Visual Narrative in Motion Graphics
motionGraphics.description: Students acquire project experience refining skills in communication, research, critical analysis and criticism, while exploring visual story construction, graphic workflows and process pipelines for motion-based applications. Topics include story conceptualizing and structures, project management, visual composition and motion graphic techniques.
requirements: GIT 312 OR Visiting University Student

allFocusAreas.name: Topic: Creative Agency
allFocusAreas.description: Covers topics of immediate or special interest to a faculty member and students.
requirements: Instructor consent

allFocusAreas.name: Topic: Creative Agency 2
allFocusAreas.description: Covers topics of immediate or special interest to a faculty member and students.
requirements: Instructor consent

allFocusAreas.name: Honors Directed Study
allFocusAreas.description: Independent study in which a student, under the supervision of a faculty member, conducts research or creative work that is expected to lead to an undergraduate honors thesis or creative project.
requirements: Department consent
Barrett Honors student

allFocusAreas.name: Honors Thesis
allFocusAreas.description: Supervised research or creative activity focused on preparation and completion of an undergraduate honors thesis or creative project.
requirements: Department consent
Barrett Honors student
ENG 101, 105, or 107 with C or better

allFocusAreas.name: Individualized Instruction
allFocusAreas.description: Provides an opportunity for original study or investigation in the major or field of specialization, on an individual and more autonomous basis.
requirements: Instructor consent
